title: Sun4Schools - Decentralized Solar Crowdfunding for Schools
summary: Mauritian schools face high electricity costs and lack upfront capital for solar systems. No transparent, community-driven mechanism exists to fund renewable energy and reduce this financial burden.
solution: A blockchain-based crowdfunding platform that lets citizens and diaspora fund school solar projects transparently, enabling affordable clean energy, lower costs, and community-driven impact.

sub_fields.answer: The Sun4Schools decentralized crowdfunding platform depends on a wide ecosystem of government institutions, regulatory bodies, technical partners, energy authorities, and implementation partners. These dependencies are essential for regulatory compliance, data exchange, grid integration, school participation, and long-term sustainability. The dependencies fall into four major categories: Regulatory, Governmental & Institutional, Technical, and Operational/Implementation.  1. Regulatory Dependencies a. Financial Services Commission (FSC) ‚Äì Crowdfunding Licensing Sun4Schools interacts directly with the Financial Services (Crowdfunding) Rules 2021, which regulate all crowdfunding activities in Mauritius. The platform depends on FSC authorization for: ‚Ä¢	Crowdfunding operator licensing ‚Ä¢	Investment limits ‚Ä¢	KYC/AML compliance ‚Ä¢	Due diligence obligations for issuers and contributors Any delay or change in FSC regulatory approval may impact the timing of onboarding contributors or formally launching the platform. b. VAITOS Act 2021 ‚Äì Virtual Assets & Tokenization Rules Because the solution uses blockchain, tokenized contributions, and crypto payments, it must comply with the Virtual Asset and Initial Token Offering Services (VAITOS) Act. This introduces dependencies on: ‚Ä¢	VASP licensing (if tokenization or on-chain assets are activated) ‚Ä¢	ITO registration (for fractional ownership or solar tokens) ‚Ä¢	Data protection safeguards for on-chain metadata c. Bank of Mauritius & Economic Development Board ‚Äì Regulatory Sandbox Authorization The solution may require RSA approval to operate as an innovative FinTech use case, especially during the MVP. This sandbox provides a controlled environment for blockchain pilots, especially while tokenization and smart contracts are not yet fully regulated for government-linked services.  2. Governmental & Institutional Dependencies a. Ministry of Education (MoE) ‚Äì School Participation & Approvals Since the pilot targets Mauritian public schools, the project heavily depends on the Ministry of Education for: ‚Ä¢	Approving participating schools ‚Ä¢	Allowing site assessments & roof inspections ‚Ä¢	Validating school-level energy data ‚Ä¢	Coordinating with school administrators Without MoE authorization, the pilot cannot begin. b. Ministry of Information Technology, Communication and Innovation (MITCI) MITCI is expected to host the platform on the Government Cloud / Government Online Centre during the pilot rollout. Dependencies include: ‚Ä¢	Cloud hosting approval ‚Ä¢	Government DevOps/security compliance ‚Ä¢	Integration with national digital identity tools (future phases) c. Central Electricity Board (CEB) ‚Äì Grid Integration & Tariff Structures CEB is a critical dependency, as the platform cannot function without energy data and grid-connection approvals. Dependencies include: ‚Ä¢	Access to the Gross Metering or MSDG schemes ‚Ä¢	PPA validation ‚Ä¢	Production meter and export meter installation ‚Ä¢	Verification of solar generation data for dashboards Delays in CEB approvals directly delay school onboarding. d. Government of Mauritius (Policy Alignment) The project depends on national targets and ministerial commitments under: ‚Ä¢	Renewable Energy Roadmap 2030 ‚Ä¢	Energy & climate policies (60% renewable targets) ‚Ä¢	UNSDCF & UNDP Country Programme alignment Changes in policy may affect tariff revenue, investor appeal, or school selection.  3. Technical Dependencies a. Socious Fund (Solution Maker) Responsible for: ‚Ä¢	Blockchain integration ‚Ä¢	Platform backend & frontend ‚Ä¢	Smart-contract automation ‚Ä¢	Wallet integration ‚Ä¢	Tokenization features Since developer time is limited, technical capacity is a dependency and potential risk. b. Cardano Infrastructure The project requires: ‚Ä¢	Stable access to Cardano mainnet ‚Ä¢	Wallet compatibility (Yoroi, Nami, Lace, etc.) ‚Ä¢	Low-fee ADA transaction environment ‚Ä¢	Metadata tagging, UTxO handling, smart contract execution Any major blockchain network outage or protocol change affects the MVP. c. Self-Sovereign Identity (SSI) / Hyperledger Identus Used for: ‚Ä¢	KYC/AML compliance ‚Ä¢	Private, verifiable identity checks The SSI stack is external, therefore availability and compatibility are dependencies. d. External Payment Providers (e.g., Stripe) For fiat contributors, dependency includes availability of Stripe or other approved gateways for Mauritian users. e. Government Data Systems For future phases: ‚Ä¢	Integration with MITCI‚Äôs national super-app ‚Ä¢	Integration with future national digital wallets These require government engineering coordination.  4. Operational & Implementation Dependencies a. Solar PV Installers (CEB-approved EPCs) Solar installation, maintenance, and technical verification depend on certified installers. Dependencies include: ‚Ä¢	Site assessment accuracy ‚Ä¢	Compliance with CEB grid codes ‚Ä¢	Speed of installation ‚Ä¢	Maintenance and post-installation support b. School Administrators & PTAs Operational dependencies include: ‚Ä¢	Providing access to school premises ‚Ä¢	Coordinating communications with communities ‚Ä¢	Supporting awareness campaigns c. Contributors, Diaspora, CSR Actors The project relies on community participation for: ‚Ä¢	Funding campaigns ‚Ä¢	CSR sponsorship and blended finance Without sufficient contributor activity, project scaling slows. d. UNDP Mauritius & Seychelles UNDP provides: ‚Ä¢	Strategic oversight ‚Ä¢	Stakeholder coordination ‚Ä¢	M&E support UNDP‚Äôs support is essential for convening ministries and development partners.  5. Financial Dependencies a. Donors and Climate Financing Partners The pilot depends on resource mobilization: Potential contributors: ‚Ä¢	CSR funds ‚Ä¢	Private sector ‚Ä¢	GCF, GEF, AfDB, EU, etc. b. Catalyst Funding Catalyst funds are required to complete: ‚Ä¢	Blockchain components ‚Ä¢	Smart contracts ‚Ä¢	Wallet integration ‚Ä¢	Field testing ‚Ä¢	Tokenization modules Without this funding, the MVP cannot reach pilot readiness.  6. Legal & Governance Dependencies a. Data Protection Act (Mauritius) The platform must comply with national privacy rules for: ‚Ä¢	User data ‚Ä¢	Energy data from schools ‚Ä¢	Investor identity verification b. Governance Body / Joint Oversight Committee A governance structure involving MoE, CEB, MITCI, UNDP, and Socious is required to safeguard transparency and long-term sustainability.  Conclusion The Sun4Schools project has several critical dependencies across regulatory, governmental, technical, operational, financial, and governance domains. These dependencies are expected and appropriate for a national-level renewable energy and blockchain initiative. They ensure that the platform remains compliant, secure, scalable, and properly integrated with public institutions and national infrastructure. All dependencies are manageable but require active coordination, especially with the Ministry of Education, CEB, FSC, MITCI, and the Cardano technical ecosystem.

sub_fields.title: Describe what makes your idea innovative compared to what has been previously launched in the market (whether by you or others).
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
Sun4Schools introduces a new financing model that does not currently exist in Mauritius or in most global education systems: a blockchain-powered, community-driven crowdfunding platform specifically designed to finance solar energy for public schools. While solar projects and crowdfunding each exist independently, no existing solution combines:



1. Decentralized financing of public solar assets

Most renewable energy projects rely on government budgets, loans, or private developers. Sun4Schools makes solar funding open to anyone, including parents, diaspora, youth, and CSR contributors‚Äîdemocratizing access to clean-energy investment.



2. Transparent ADA-based contributions

Unlike traditional donation portals, Sun4Schools uses Cardano blockchain transactions and metadata to provide tamper-proof transparency. Every contribution is traceable, verifiable, and permanently recorded‚Äîsomething conventional crowdfunding platforms cannot offer.



3. Fractional ownership via tokenization

Future phases introduce tokenized fractions of solar assets, allowing people to ‚Äúown‚Äù parts of school solar systems and receive verifiable impact data. This is a significant innovation compared to legacy CSR or donation models that offer no traceability or ownership.



4. Integrated smart contracts for energy revenue

Legacy systems rely on manual invoicing and opaque accounting. Sun4Schools plans to automate:

‚Ä¢	Payments

‚Ä¢	Allocation of funds

‚Ä¢	PPA processes

via Plutus smart contracts, reducing administrative overhead and increasing trust.



5. On-chain environmental impact tracking

The platform links:

‚Ä¢	kWh generated

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ avoided

‚Ä¢	School energy savings

to on-chain records, creating auditable SDG impact reporting‚Äîa feature not found in traditional crowdfunding or solar procurement systems.



6. A first-of-its-kind model for public schools in SIDS

While a few global platforms (e.g., Sun Exchange) finance private/commercial solar, no platform globally offers decentralized, blockchain-backed solar crowdfunding for government schools‚Äîespecially in Small Island Developing States (SIDS) with high energy costs and climate vulnerability.



7. Government integration and regulatory alignment

Sun4Schools uniquely combines:

‚Ä¢	Crowdfunding rules

‚Ä¢	Virtual asset regulations

‚Ä¢	CEB energy schemes

‚Ä¢	Ministry of Education participation

‚Ä¢	Government cloud hosting

This creates a nationally compliant, institutional-grade blockchain application, unlike typical startup-led solar crowdfunding.



Why it is innovative overall



Sun4Schools is not just another crowdfunding tool or solar project‚Äîit is a new category of public infrastructure financing that blends:



clean energy + blockchain + community empowerment + transparent impact tracking.

It replaces opaque, centralized funding models with a trustless, open, efficient, and inclusive mechanism powered by Cardano. No comparable solution exists in Mauritius, the region, or the global public-school sector.

The prototype and MVP demonstrate how Sun4Schools enables transparent, community-driven crowdfunding of solar projects for Mauritian public schools using ADA and fiat contributions. The platform showcases the full user journey, including browsing school projects, viewing funding needs, making a contribution, and seeing real-time progress indicators such as kWh impact, CO‚ÇÇ savings, and funds raised.



The MVP also includes core features such as:



- Project listings and impact dashboards
- ADA payment flow simulation
- Contributor verification (KYC/SSI)
- Role-based access for school admins, government, and investors
- Early logic for fractional ownership and tokenization
- Basic admin approval workflow



These elements validate usability, interface design, and the decentralized funding model before completing smart contracts, token minting, and blockchain automation in the full pilot.



The prototype can be accessed at:

sub_fields.title: Describe realistic measures of success, ideally with on-chain metrics.
sub_fields.description: Please provide your rationale.
sub_fields.answer:
Realistic Measures of Success (Including On-Chain Metrics)

Success for Sun4Schools is measured by real user adoption, successful funding of school solar projects, and verifiable on-chain activity recorded on the Cardano blockchain.

 1. On-Chain Contribution Metrics

‚Ä¢	Number of ADA contributions recorded on-chain

‚Ä¢	Total ADA value contributed to school solar projects

‚Ä¢	Unique contributor wallets participating in campaigns

‚Ä¢	On-chain metadata records linked to each contribution (project ID, school ID, amount, timestamp)

‚Ä¢	Transaction volume per project, showing traction for each school

These metrics provide transparent, immutable evidence of community engagement.



2. On-Chain Asset & Token Metrics (Pilot Phase)

‚Ä¢	Number of fractional solar tokens minted (representing ownership or impact units)

‚Ä¢	Distribution count of tokens to contributor wallets

‚Ä¢	Smart contract events triggered, such as funding completion or revenue distribution

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ-impact or kWh-impact metadata written to Cardano for verification

These demonstrate the real-world utility of decentralized renewable energy assets on Cardano.



3. Platform & User Adoption Metrics (Off-chain but verifiable)

‚Ä¢	Number of registered users (local + diaspora + CSR)

‚Ä¢	Number of schools onboarded (target: 5 for pilot)

‚Ä¢	Funding goal completion rate for each school

‚Ä¢	Total amount raised (ADA + fiat) across all campaigns

‚Ä¢	Repeat contribution rate (contributors returning for new projects)

These validate that the system works for real users and institutions.

4. Real-World Impact Metrics

‚Ä¢	kWh of clean energy generated by funded solar systems

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ emissions avoided, linked to on-chain records

‚Ä¢	Reduction in school electricity bills (quantified monthly)

‚Ä¢	Percentage of school operations powered by solar

These demonstrate tangible SDG impact and public value.



5. Government & Institutional Integration Metrics

‚Ä¢	API calls and data events transmitted from CEB (solar generation, export tariff data)

‚Ä¢	Operational dashboards used by Ministry of Education and UNDP

‚Ä¢	Regulatory compliance milestones achieved (FSC/VAITOS/Sandbox)

These confirm institutional adoption and long-term sustainability.

sub_fields.title: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.description: Please describe your proposed solution and how it addresses the problem
sub_fields.answer:
Sun4Schools is a blockchain-enabled crowdfunding platform that enables citizens, diaspora, CSR actors, and impact-driven contributors to fund solar photovoltaic (PV) installations for Mauritian public schools in a transparent, secure, and inclusive way. The platform allows anyone to contribute small or large amounts‚Äî via fiat‚Äîto specific school projects, with every contribution transparently recorded on the Cardano blockchain.



The solution directly addresses the main barrier faced by schools: lack of upfront capital for solar systems. Instead of relying on limited government budgets, Sun4Schools unlocks a new, community-driven financing mechanism that mobilizes funding from a broad contributor base. By aggregating small contributions, the platform enables schools to access renewable energy schemes (e.g., Gross Metering, Solar PV Scheme for Educational Institutions) and reduce long-term electricity costs.



The platform provides real-time project visibility, including funds raised, installation status, kWh generated, CO‚ÇÇ reduced, and financial savings for schools. Future phases introduce fractional ownership through tokenization and smart contracts to automate fund flows and power-purchase agreements. This builds trust, ensures accountability, and enables verifiable impact reporting aligned with national renewable energy targets and SDG goals.



By combining clean energy, digital inclusion, and transparent financing, Sun4Schools creates a scalable model that reduces school electricity expenses, empowers communities to participate in climate action, and demonstrates real-world utility of Cardano for public infrastructure financing.

sub_fields.title: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.description: Please define the positive impact your project will have on the wider Cardano community
sub_fields.answer:
Sun4Schools strengthens the Cardano ecosystem by demonstrating a real-world, regulated, and legally compliant use of Cardano where end users never touch cryptocurrency. Instead, the platform uses fiat payments, while Cardano operates in the backend to provide trust, transparency, and automation.

1. A Real-World Government-Linked Use Case for Cardano, Without Crypto Payments

Since crypto payments are not allowed in Mauritius, Sun4Schools uses traditional fiat payment gateways, but still leverages Cardano for:

‚Ä¢	immutable record-keeping of contributions,

‚Ä¢	verifiable timestamps and project metadata,

‚Ä¢	transparent tracking of fund flow and project status.

This showcases a powerful model: Cardano as digital public infrastructure, not a payment tool.

2. Transparent, auditable crowdfunding using on-chain metadata

All contributions (made in fiat) are hashed and recorded onto Cardano with:

‚Ä¢	project ID

‚Ä¢	amount

‚Ä¢	timestamp

‚Ä¢	milestone reached

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ or kWh impact snapshots

This demonstrates how Cardano can be used for public auditing systems, a growing need in global development, UN agencies, and governments.

3. Tokenization for impact reporting, not financial ownership

The platform introduces non-financial impact tokens (not tradable, not speculative), which represent:

‚Ä¢	solar capacity funded

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ impact units

‚Ä¢	contribution badges (digital credentials)

This aligns with Mauritius regulations and demonstrates a safe, compliance-friendly token use case on Cardano.

4. Smart contracts used internally to automate trust

Plutus smart contracts are used internally (not exposed to users) to automate:

‚Ä¢	milestone validation

‚Ä¢	project unlock stages

‚Ä¢	fund-release logic

‚Ä¢	EPC/installer verification events

This shows how Cardano can streamline public-sector processes even when users interact only with fiat interfaces.

5. Cardano as a digital backbone for SDG-aligned development

The project generates on-chain climate and infrastructure data, including:

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ avoided

‚Ä¢	solar generation impact

‚Ä¢	school energy savings

‚Ä¢	progress towards national renewable goals

This positions Cardano as the blockchain of choice for SDG monitoring, climate finance, and public-impact tracking, an area with rising global demand.

6. Onboards institutions‚Äînot crypto users‚Äîinto Cardano‚Äôs ecosystem

The project introduces Cardano to:

‚Ä¢	the Ministry of Education

‚Ä¢	MITCI (IT ministry)

‚Ä¢	CEB (energy authority)

‚Ä¢	UNDP and development partners

‚Ä¢	schools and PTAs

‚Ä¢	CSR foundations and private-sector donors

This is high-value institutional exposure that greatly strengthens Cardano‚Äôs reputation as a trusted, enterprise-ready blockchain.

7. Establishes a replicable blueprint for compliant ‚Äúfiat-in / blockchain-backend‚Äù models

This approach can be reused by:

‚Ä¢	health facilities

‚Ä¢	municipalities

‚Ä¢	CSR-funded public projects

‚Ä¢	community renewable energy initiatives

‚Ä¢	international development partners

This expands the range of regulatory-compliant Cardano deployments in countries that do not allow crypto.

sub_fields.title: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.description: What is your capability to deliver your project with high levels of trust and accountability? How do you intend to validate if your approach is feasible?
sub_fields.answer:
Sun4Schools is delivered through a multi-institutional partnership combining UNDP‚Äôs governance and public-sector experience with Socious Fund‚Äôs technical expertise in building secure, transparent digital platforms. This structure ensures strong accountability, regulatory compliance, and institutional oversight.



1. Strong Institutional Capacity (UNDP)

UNDP Mauritius brings:

‚Ä¢	Longstanding collaboration with the Government of Mauritius

‚Ä¢	Experience implementing renewable energy, digital transformation, and climate resilience projects

‚Ä¢	Proven monitoring, evaluation, and reporting frameworks

‚Ä¢	Transparent procurement and risk-management systems

‚Ä¢	Direct access to ministries (Education, MITCI, Energy) for alignment and validation

UNDP‚Äôs involvement ensures the project follows international standards, ethical guidelines, and full regulatory compliance.



2. Technical Capacity (Socious Fund)

Socious Fund provides:

‚Ä¢	A functioning prototype platform

‚Ä¢	Expertise in secure backend development, dashboards, identity verification, and modular system design

‚Ä¢	Experience integrating blockchain as a transparent backend ledger without exposing users to crypto

‚Ä¢	Ability to implement tokenization and smart-contract automation in a compliance-friendly environment

The team has already built core modules, demonstrating capability and readiness to deliver the MVP and pilot.



3. Government Partnerships Enable Trust

Project delivery is supported by:

‚Ä¢	Ministry of Education (school selection, site access, administrative support)

‚Ä¢	MITCI (government cloud hosting & cybersecurity compliance)

‚Ä¢	Central Electricity Board (CEB) (energy generation data, tariff structures, verification of impact)

These institutions ensure that the project is anchored in national policy objectives and supported by reliable data sources.



4. Built-in Transparency & Accountability Measures

Even with fiat payments, the system employs:

‚Ä¢	Blockchain-backed verification (hashed contributions, milestone records, installation data)

‚Ä¢	Role-based access controls for schools, CEB, donors, and regulators

‚Ä¢	Audit trails for every action, contribution, and project update

‚Ä¢	Open dashboards showing project progress, energy production, and impact

This allows donors, ministries, and schools to independently verify progress.



How We Intend to Validate the Feasibility of the Approach



1. Comprehensive Feasibility Study (Months 1‚Äì3)

The project begins with a structured feasibility assessment including:

‚Ä¢	Technical reviews of school roofs, electrical infrastructure, and PV installation conditions

‚Ä¢	Verification of CEB scheme applicability (Gross Metering / School RE Scheme)

‚Ä¢	Legal review under FSC Crowdfunding Rules and VAITOS Act

‚Ä¢	Economic modelling of cost savings and installation ROI

‚Ä¢	Stakeholder interviews with schools, ministries, and installers

This ensures the model is practical, legal, and technically implementable.



2. Pilot Deployment With 5 Schools

A small, manageable pilot will validate:

‚Ä¢	Platform usability

‚Ä¢	Willingness of schools and communities to participate

‚Ä¢	Accuracy of energy and cost-savings projections

‚Ä¢	Integration with CEB for energy data

‚Ä¢	Government cloud hosting readiness

‚Ä¢	Operational coordination with installers

‚Ä¢	Community trust and donor engagement

This pilot becomes the evidence base for national rollout.



3. Continuous Validation Through Data

Validation is supported by real operational data:

‚Ä¢	Energy generated (kWh)

‚Ä¢	CO‚ÇÇ emissions avoided

‚Ä¢	Electricity savings for schools

‚Ä¢	Funding success rate across projects

‚Ä¢	User participation and repeat engagement

‚Ä¢	On-chain audit records validating transparency

This provides proof that the approach works in practice.



4. Iterative Feedback Loops

Feedback will be collected from:

‚Ä¢	School administrators

‚Ä¢	Parents and community donors

‚Ä¢	Diaspora contributors

‚Ä¢	Government partners

‚Ä¢	Solar installers

‚Ä¢	CEB technical staff

This feedback informs continuous improvements in UI, workflows, trust mechanisms, and impact reporting.



5. Compliance Checks With Regulators

The project includes ongoing review with:

‚Ä¢	FSC (Crowdfunding compliance)

‚Ä¢	MITCI (security, hosting, data protection)

‚Ä¢	CEB (technical validation)

‚Ä¢	Ministry of Education (operational alignment)

Feasibility is validated not only technically but also legally and institutionally.

sub_fields.title: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.description: How does the cost of the project represent value for the Cardano ecosystem?
sub_fields.answer:
The USD 200,000 budget delivers significant value to the Cardano ecosystem because it funds a real, government-linked, national-level pilot that demonstrates how Cardano can be used as a trusted transparency and public-impact infrastructure‚Äîwithout requiring crypto payments, ensuring full regulatory compliance. This creates a replicable model for dozens of countries where crypto is restricted but blockchain adoption is possible.



1. Investment into a High-Visibility, Real-World Cardano Use Case



The project shows Cardano being deployed in the public sector to track funding, milestones, and climate impact for solar installations in schools. This is one of the strongest forms of Cardano utility‚Äîreal-world transformation with measurable outcomes.



2. Open-Source Components Reusable by the Community



Most of the platform‚Äôs blockchain-related elements‚Äîmetadata hashing, impact token logic (non-financial), smart-contract automation frameworks, and transparency modules‚Äîwill be released open source. This allows other Cardano builders to reuse, modify, and scale these tools at zero cost.



3. Demonstrates Cardano‚Äôs Role in SDG Impact Finance



The project becomes a blueprint for how Cardano can support:



climate action tracking



renewable-energy impact reporting



public-sector transparency



community-driven funding models



This strengthens Cardano‚Äôs standing as a blockchain for sustainability, inclusion, and development.



4. Institutional Onboarding into the Cardano ecosystem



A portion of the project cost supports coordination with:



Ministry of Education



MITCI (IT Ministry)



CEB



UNDP

These institutions learn and interact with Cardano-backed systems, expanding institutional trust and long-term adoption potential.



5. Large-Scale Social Visibility for Cardano (Public + Government)



The awareness campaign introduces Cardano‚Äôs transparency features to thousands of parents, teachers, students, CSR foundations, and community partners‚Äîeven without using crypto. This elevates Cardano‚Äôs visibility in a regulated but tech-forward context.



6. Technical Development Strengthens Cardano‚Äôs Developer Ecosystem



Most of the budget (USD 150,000) funds skilled developers building:



metadata-linked records



non-financial impact token modules



smart contract automation



blockchain transparency APIs



secure enterprise-grade backend

These are direct technical assets for Cardano‚Äôs ecosystem.



7. A Scalable Model That Can Be Replicated Globally



Because the solution is fiat-in / blockchain-backend, it can be adopted in:



Africa



Small Island Developing States



Asia



Latin America

where crypto restrictions exist.

Catalyst funds the first implementation, but the model can scale to hundreds of schools worldwide, growing Cardano‚Äôs footprint exponentially.



8. Measurable On-Chain Impact Metrics



The project produces verifiable Cardano-linked metrics:



hashed records of contributions



on-chain impact snapshots (CO‚ÇÇ avoided, kWh generated)



tokenized impact badges

This demonstrates meaningful blockchain utility beyond financial products.
